metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeal Nos. 151 of 1997 and 227 of 1997

facts.text: Baldev Singh married Manmohan Kaur in 1979.
Baldev Singh harassed Manmohan Kaur for bringing insufficient dowry, with continuing demand of Rs.30,000/-.
On 21st June 1985, Manmohan Kaur visited her father's house in village Nangal Thindal, complained of harassment and dowry demand, left her three-year-old daughter there.
Harbans Singh (PW4, father) sent her back to matrimonial home with assurance to settle matter.
On 22nd June 1985 at about 2.35 p.m., Baldev Singh informed Harbans Singh that Manmohan Kaur missing since early morning.
Harbans Singh asked Baldev to search thoroughly, informed of dowry harassment by Baldev, parents, sisters, sisters-in-law, brothers.
Harbans Singh searched with relatives but failed; on return on 23rd June, learnt dead body traced by in-laws.
Harbans Singh rushed to in-laws' house, saw dead body of Manmohan Kaur being consigned to flames at cremation ground.
In-laws (Baldev Singh and parents) said body cremated after informing Police, completing formalities, as decomposing and could not wait.

On 24th June 1985, Harbans Singh filed written application (Exhibit PD) to Senior Superintendent of Police, Hoshiarpur, suspecting murder by in-laws for insufficient dowry, naming appellants, Baldev Singh, father.
Complaint sent to SHO on 4th July 1985, prima facie under Section 306 IPC, FIR registered under Section 306 IPC.
Investigation conducted, challan filed, case committed to Sessions Court for trial under Section 306/201 IPC.
Harbans Singh filed criminal complaint under Section 302/201/149 IPC, committed to Sessions, consolidated with police case.
Sessions Court: Acquitted all of Section 302 and 302/149; Baldev Singh guilty under Section 306; appellants acquitted under 306 but guilty under 201 IPC, sentenced to RI 1 year and fine.
High Court by common judgment: Dismissed appeals by State, Harbans Singh (against acquittal), and appellants (against 201 conviction); confirmed acquittal under 306, Baldev's conviction under 306.
Appellants in Crl. A. No.151/1997: Family members of Baldev Singh - Appellant Nos.3&5 brothers, No.4 wife of No.3, No.6 wife of No.5, No.7 sister; No.2 mother (died, appeal abated).
Harjap Singh sole appellant in Crl. A. No.227/1997, family friend of Baldev Singh.
Sessions Court found: Harbans Singh (PW4) with PW8 Darshan Singh reached cremation ground, pyre burning, all accused present; accused said body in house before cremation, no autopsy.
Acquittal under 306 attained finality; Baldev's conviction under 306 final.

legal_issues.text: Correctness of conviction of appellants under Section 201 IPC.

respondent_arguments.text: Accused (family members and friend) knew of death and missing, present at cremation (per PW4,5,8), cremated without informing police/Harbans, acted to eliminate evidence of Section 306 offence.

court_reasoning.text: Mere presence at house/cremation ground or relationship with Baldev Singh does not attract Section 201 IPC; no presumption of knowledge of offence from these facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only findings: family members/friend, present at house and cremation; no other evidence.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence appellants knew or had reason to believe offence under Section 306 committed by Baldev and participated in cremation to conceal; cannot assume on suspicion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sessions/High Court concluded haste in cremation without informing parents/police indicates knowledge, but insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: To establish Section 201 IPC, must prove offence committed (not mere suspicion), accused knew/reason to believe, and with intent to screen offender caused evidence to disappear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Palvinder Kaur requiring proof beyond suspicion.

holdings.text: Conviction under Section 201 IPC cannot be sustained without evidence of knowledge/reason to believe offence committed and intent to screen offender; mere presence/relation insufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Essential to prove offence committed (not suspicion), knowledge/reason to believe, and intent to screen by causing evidence to disappear.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suleman Rahiman Mulani & Anr. v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Palvinder Kaur on requirements for Section 201 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nathu & Anr. v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Palvinder Kaur on requirements for Section 201 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: V.L. Tresa v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Palvinder Kaur on requirements for Section 201 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 201 requires knowledge of commission of offence (here 306 by Baldev) and intent to screen by disappearing evidence; appellants acquitted of 306/302.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; conviction of appellants under Section 201 IPC set aside and quashed; acquitted.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal from offence under Section 201 IPC

key_quotes.text: "Mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would not attract the provision of Section 201 IPC."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects lower courts' basis for conviction.

key_quotes.text: "Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In absence of evidence, it cannot be assumed on suspicion alone that the appellants must have known or must have reason to believe..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
